Despite the challenges he faced, Fox continued to star in numerous successful movies and television shows throughout the 1990s, including "Spin City" (1996-2002), "Anchorman: The Legend of Ron Burgundy" (2004), and "Team Captain" (2006-2007). It's never too late to write a biography about Michael J. Fox, the beloved actor and philanthropist. Here's a short biography to get you started:

Michael Jeffrey Fox (born June 9, 1961) is an iconic Canadian-American actor, producer, and advocate for Parkinson's disease research. Fox is best known for his roles as Marty McFly in the Back to the Future trilogy, Alex P. Keaton in Family Ties, and Mike Flaherty on Spin City. He has received two Academy Awards, two Golden Globes, and two Primetime Emmy Awards throughout his illustrious career.

Fox was born in Toronto, Ontario, Canada, to a Canadian mother, Janet, and a British-born American father, Howard Fox. The family moved to the United States when Michael was 11, and he grew up in Peekskill, New York. He attended Peekskill High School and later transferred to Horace Mann School in New York City, where he began to pursue acting seriously.

After graduating from the Carnegie Institute of Technology (now Carnegie Mellon University) in 1982 with a degree in communications, Fox moved to Los Angeles and landed his breakthrough role in the comedy series Family Ties. His talent and likable personality catapulted him to superstardom, and his characters quickly became iconic.

In 1985, Fox starred in his first blockbuster hit, the Back to the Future film series. He reprised the role of Marty McFly in Back to the Future Part III in 1990, before moving on to other projects. Fox's roles in other popular films, such as The Secret of My Success, Ninja Assassin, The Secret Life of Walter Mitty, and Bobby (which earned him an Academy Award nomination), solidified his status as a leading actor in Hollywood.

Besides his career on the silver screen, Fox has been open about his battle with Parkinson's disease, which he was diagnosed with in 1991. Determined to make a difference, Fox founded the Michael J. Fox Foundation for Parkinson's Research in 2000, which aims to find a cure for the disease.
